identificationModule.briefTitle: Motivating Occupational Virtual Experiences In Therapy for Kids
identificationModule.officialTitle: Motivating Occupational Virtual Experiences In Therapy for Kids (MOVE-IT)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: A rater-blinded randomized controlled trial (RCT) will be conducted to compare the efficacy of MOVE-IT use in a remotely supervised home exercise program (HEP) to usual care for recovery of upper extremity (UE) function in children with hemiplegia.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
A rater-blinded randomized controlled trial (RCT) will be conducted to compare the efficacy of MOVE-IT use in a remotely supervised home exercise program (HEP) to usual care for recovery of upper extremity (UE) function in children with hemiplegia, and to acquire evidence of usability and acceptance of the MOVE-IT system by children and parents. The University of Virginia (UVA) will serve as coordinating center and single IRB for the two-site RCT that includes UVA and Duke University.

The primary Phase II investigational objective is to show a differential effect on the pre- to post-intervention change in UE motor function between an interventional group receiving the MOVE-IT HEP and a usual care treatment (UCT) group, as assessed by the Jebsen Tailor Hand Function Test (JTHFT), a time-based measure of functional hand motor skills, and other gold-standard clinical instruments for UE function including the Quality of Upper Extremity Skills Test (QUEST), with qualitative assessment of discrete movements, and the Wolf Motor Function Test (WMFT), which includes both quantitative and qualitative assessment of functional movements.

The pre-to-post intervention change in the composite JTHFT score will be the primary endpoint for the Phase II efficacy study. Secondary analysis will include pre-to-post intervention changes in the composite QUEST and WMFT scores.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription:
Intervention group performs home exercise program using the computer-aided MOVE-IT system for upper extremity therapy.

Control group participants will be followed as they continue to receive their previously prescribed therapy services.

maskingInfo.maskingDescription: Investigator administrating assessments will be blinded to subject group assignment.

armGroups.label: MOVE-IT Home Exercise Program (HEP)
armGroups.description: Participants will be asked to employ the MOVE-IT system for upper extremity practice at home 1 hour/day, 5 days/week over a 10-week period.

armGroups.label: Usual Care Treatment (UCT) Control
armGroups.description: Children in the UCT group will be followed as they continue to receive their previously prescribed therapy services. These children will not receive any treatment services through the study as UCT group participants.

interventions.name: MOVE-IT Intervention
interventions.description: The MOVE-IT device comprises a custom smart toy and therapy game software to enable repetitive task practice involving the arm and hand.

interventions.name: UCT Control
interventions.description: Participants assigned to the UCT control group will continue to receive their previously prescribed therapy services.

primaryOutcomes.description: Time-based measure of functional hand motor skills

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Quality of Upper Extremity Skills Test (QUEST)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Aggregate score based on individual scores for dissociated movements and grasp components
WMFT-TIME is a quantitative measure calculated using the average time to complete the individual tasks within the WMFT.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Pediatric Evaluation and Disability Inventory Computer Adaptive Test (PEDI-CAT)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Parental report instrument of upper extremity motor function
Parental report instrument of upper extremity motor function

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Wolf Motor Function Test - Functional Assessment (WMFT-FA)
secondaryOutcomes.description: WMFT Functional Assessment (FA) score is a qualitative assessment based on scoring of each functional task using a 6-point ordinal rating scale that ranges from 0 (no use of the affected hand attempted) to 5 (normal function). A total WMFT-FA is calculated by taking the average across all tasks.
